Description: The Justice Department announced a settlement agreement under the Americans with Disabilities Act with Blockbuster Inc. to ensure equal access to its stores nationwide for individuals with disabilities who use service animals.

As the result of Do Not Call litigation brought by the U.S. Department of Justice on behalf of the Federal Trade Commission, as well as the states of California, Illinois, North Carolina, and Ohio, a federal court in Illinois ordered penalties totaling $280 million and strong injunctive relief against Englewood, Colorado-based satellite television provider Dish Network.

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: overtime violation

The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Fair Credit Reporting Act by failing to provide proper disclosure and authorization before obtaining consumer background reports on technicans and took adverse employment actions based on those reports without providing workers copies of the reports and notice of their rights. DISH Networks settled separately from Sterling Infosystems, which provided the reports (see separate entry for Sterling).
Private Litigation Case Title: Ernst v. Dish Network, LLC et al

Description: Blockbuster Inc. agreed to settle multistate litigation alleging tha it misled consumers in advertising its End of Late Fees or No Late Fees program.
deceptive surchages
DISH Network agreed to pay $2 million in settlement of allegations it failed to clearly disclose possible price increases during a contract in its sales calls.

DISH Network agreed to pay $5.9 million as part of the settlement of multistate litigation alleging that it refused to accept responsibility for misconduct by its third-party retailers and installers; violated do-not-call rules; failed to disclose all key terms and conditions of their customer agreements; did not disclose that purchased or leased equipment was previously used and/or refurbished; charged customer credit cards and debited bank accounts without providing adequate notice and obtaining appropriate authorization; and committed other violations.
Do Not Call violation
disability
Notes: Description field shows type of discrimination that EEOC had alleged.

Description: Blockbuster agreed to pay $300,000 in settlement of allegations by the District Attorneys of Los Angeles and San Diego counties that it charged customers more than the advertised or posted price at checkouts.
religion

Info Source: Extracted from a spreadsheet obtained from the NLRB through a Freedom of Information Act request fulfilled on 5/28/2020.

Description: DISH Network LLC agreed to pay $126 million in civil penalties to the United States for placing millions of telemarketing calls in violation of the Federal Trade Commission's Telemarketing Sales Rule (TSR).  At the same time, it agreed to pay $84 million to settle litigation on the issue brough by a group of states; see separate entry.

Dish Network agreed to pay $210 million to resolve a long-running multistate lawsuit alleging that the company engaged in illegal telemarketing. In 2017, a district court found Dish violated telemarketing laws through millions of illegal telemarketing calls to sell and promote its satellite TV services and programming packages, including unwanted robocalls to thousands of people registered on the Do Not Call registry. Dish Network had appealed the ruling. The settlement was also announced by the U.S. Justice Department; see separate entry.
